Prof. A. MARSHALL ELLIOTT DEAD
Head of Romance Department Succumbs
After Lingering Illness—Was Famous
Scholar and Distinguished Man.

Dr. Aaron Marshall Elliott, the
head of the department of Romance
Languages, died at his home, 1028
North Calvert street, on the morning of Wednesday, November 9,
at 6.15 o'clock, of cancer of the
stomach, after about a year's illness.
All through the fall of 19o9, Dr.
Elliott was able to teach his classes,
although a great sufferer most of
the time. On the first of January,
last, however, his suffering became
so great that he had to give up his
work. From this time to his death
his sufferings were intense, and
although he was taken to Atlantic
City during the summer, the disease progressed so rapidly that.
when he was brought home pn
October 13, his end was daily expected.
Dr. Elliott was one of the most
brilliant men that has ever been
associated with Johns Hopkins, and
k: was through him that the Romance Language department has
acquired its international reputation.
Dr. Elliott was born in Wilmington, N. C., on January 24, 1844.
He took his A. B. at Haverford,
in 1866, and an A. M. degree from
the same college in 1878. He
studied in Europe from 1868 to
1876, at the Universities of France,
Madrid, Munich, and Vienna. On
his return he was appointed associate professor of Romance Languages at Hopkins. In 1877 he
took his Ph.D. degree from Princeton. In 1892 he was advanced to
the rank of professor of Romance
Languages, and has been the head
of the department ever since. He
received a degree of LL. D. from
Wake Forest University in 1891,
and again from Haverford in 1908.
Dr. Elliott was.one of the greatest
modern authorities on • the French
Language, and in 1907 he had the
badge of the Legion of Honor conferred upon him by the French
government, as a recognition of the
work he did in tracing the development of modern French from the
medieval dialect.
On his return from Paris he was
welcomed by Governor Warfield,
Mayor Mahool, President Remsen,
and other notable people.
Mr. George Whitelock, in 1902,
presented the University with a
life-sized painting of Dr. Elliott,
which -at present hangs in McCoy
Hall.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS
INFANT MORTALITY ASSOCIATION
Holds Instructive Meetings in McCoy
Hall with Prominent Speakers and
Interesting Educational Exhibit.

There is now being held in
McCoy Hall an exhibition which
bids fair to become famous in the
crusade for the prevention of infant
mortality. The exhibition is being
held in conjunction with the meeting of the first congress of the
American Association for Study
and Prevention of Infant Mortality.
The meeting of the Association continued through only two days,
Thursday and Friday; but the exhibition will be open until Wednesday, November 16, from io a. in.
to Jo p. m.
The opening session of the Coness was addressed by a number
of prominent men. Among them
were :" Cardinal Gibbons; M. Jusserand, the French ambassador to the
United States; Prof. Irving Fisher,
of Yale; Dr. Abraham Jacobi, of
New York, and Dr. Wm.H. Welch,
of Baltimore. They all spoke on the
subject: "The Duty of a Nation to
Its Potential Citizens." M. Jusserand told of the conditions in France
which are very similar to those in
America, and of the battle which
his nation is carrying on against
death. An association exists in
France which has adopted the
method advocated by the American
organization and met with great
success.
Prof. Irving Fisher, of New
Haven, Conn., where the American
organization was formed less than
a year ago, spoke of the work before the members and the plans
which must be pursued.
Other Hopkins men who addressed the meetings were: Dr. J.
Whitridge Williams, who told what
the obstetrician can do to prevent infant mortality,and Dr.L. F. Barker,
who spoke on the importance of
heredity and environment in the
propagation of kind.
The exhibition is being held
under the direction of the Association but there are exhibitors from
every part of the country. Some of
the exhibitors are:
The Baltimore City- Board of
Health.
The United States Department of
Agriculture.
The California Medical Milk
Commission.
The Chicago Board of Health.
New York City Department of
Health, Division of Hygiene.
Harriet Lane Hospital for Children.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOV. 14, 1910.
Little more than a month remains until the end of the time
allowed by the General Education
Board for raising the $75o,000 required to secure the quarter of a
million offered by that body to the
University. On December 31 the
sum must be actually in hand or
definitely pledged, else the other
amount will not be given. No information is available in the meanwhile bearing upon the success of
the campaign that is in progress
to secure the money, further than
the general, optimistic reports that
have been given out from time to
time. From various sources have
come informal rumors giving assurance that the amount would
surely be secured. The time is
about at hand, however, when
something more than rumor may
be expected. The importance of
the matter to the future of.the University and the profound interest
with which the outcome is being
awaited by Hopkins students cf
the past, the present, and the
future demand that some formal
announcement of the result of the
campaign be forthcoming shortly.
THE NEWS-LETTER hopes that the
news of the completion of the
fund will be made public as soon
as it reasonably can.

attention in these columns, but we
have been forced to recognize that
the mishaps to the elevator in
McCoy Hall are no longer trivial.
No serious accidents, it is true,

The Infant Morality Congress,
as one of "Pop" Christhilf's assistants called it, has proved another agreeable variation from
the routine of student life. We
have about come to the conclusion
that this thing of two congresses
a month at the University is a good
plan, and we are willing to have
the buildings cluttered up with exhibits all the year 'round, if they
will all be as interesting as the
last two. Of course some of the
students felt that it was a little
beneath their dignity to take any
notice of a baby show, but we
doubt very much if there was any
member of the University who
didn't find himself neglecting some
• duty to look just a moment at some
of those model nurseries or hospitals. It has been suggested that
quizzes on the kind and amount of
milk sold in New York or the
proper treatment for cholera morbus be substituted for the usual
ordeals in the classrooms this
month, so that credit may be gotten
for one of the by-products of a
Hopkins education.

THE NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 14, 1910

THE VOYAGE TO JAMAICA
A Member of the Biological
Expedition
Tells of the Trip from Baltimore to Port Antonio.

BY A. R. MIDDLETON,
It has been suggested to me that
an account of some of our experiences on the Hopkins Jamaica
expedition would be acceptable to
T 1E NEWS-LETTER.
On the trip down to Jamaica
several incidents occurred that seem
worthy of mention. It will be remembered by yout readers that
\v hen we sailed from Baltimore,
Halley's Comet was attracting the
attention, of everyone. We on the
ship had an especially fine opportunity of seeing it. Between three
and four o'clock on the morning
of May 13, I got up and went on
deck and I was more than paid
for the effort. • The comet was
east of. the ship, and there were
no objects to obstruct one's view
or dwarf it by comparison. Its
head was close down towards the
eastern horizon, while its tail
stretched as a broad band of light
straight up the sky, finally fading
out at the zenith itself.
The first land we sighted was
San Salvadore, and our captain
very obligingly pointed out to us
the position of the Columbus Monument.
Another interesting sight was our
view of Cuba. We vent quite close
to the eastern end of the island,
SO that every feature of its long
coast line was clearly visible to us.
In profile, near the lighthouse, the
hills show a very remarkable series
of terraces, as evidence of former
Periods of submergence of their
limestone rocks beneath the ocean.
It was surprising to see that there
was apparently no beach, the mountains of the interior ending in foothills and a high and very narrow
coastal plain which presented a low
Cliff to the waters of the Atlantic.
This cliff was perfectly honeycombed with caverns worn in it
by the waves. The vegetation
seemed sparse, the country dry,
almost arid, and 'the greater part
of the long coast presented quite
a forbidding appearance.
We,or rather, our boat, made the
acquaintance of a school of porPoises, which romped along at her
bow for quite a while. One of the
porpoises was, I am sure, given
quite a surprise in the course of his
gambols. He shad gotten off a little
to one side and had lagged behind

his fellows a little, when suddenly
he made a dart to catch up to them
and gave his snout a resounding
thump against the side of the ship.
Then, too, early one morning, we
sighted a large turtlejazily floating along on the surface of the
water. But we were possibly most
interested in the "flying fish," of
which we saw a great many. In
watching them we were reminded of
the discussion as to how they managed to propel themselves through
the air, and we all decided that they
actually fly, i. e., that there is a
vibrating motion of the "wings,"
similar to that of bird wings. We
were led to this conclusion by several reasons: First, there is a
series of ripples produced on the
surface, such as would result from
a succession of blows struck it a
short distance apart; second, we
repeatedly saw the fish change his
direction of flight, sometimes turning almost at right angles to his .
direction on leaving the water;
third, the "flights" were so long
that it seemed to us impossible that
the fish could have gained momentum enough before leaving the
water to enable him to soar so far.
Finally, we reached the conclusion
that we could distinctly see the vibratory motion of the "wings!!
We were unable to study the
plankton forms because the speed
of the ship caused the tow-net to
bound along over the surface of
the waves in long leaps.
One of the most beautiful sights
imaginable was our first view of
Jamaica. Just as the first grey light
of dawn was showing, we were
awakened by the pilot coming
aboard, and soon we were on deck.
At the side of the ship we tould
distinguish the dim outline of the
native dug-out canoe and its three
or four negro paddlers. The canoe
was racing along over the water,
secured to the ship by a tow-line
as she steamed into the harbor of
Port Antonio.
To the east, Folly Point juts far
out into the water, and at its extreme end is the Folly Point Light.
On the west, the harbor is protected
by a large island, and a series of
reefs between it and the "mainland," so that the harbor is only
open towards the north. There is
a very narrow but comfortable
channel for the steamships,of which
there are an abundance. It is said
that Port Antonio clears more ships
Eor American ports than any other
city in the world. The town is
built on a narrow coastal plain; the

FOOT BALL
U. S. NAVAL ACADEMY

mountains are so close that from
the deck of a ship in the port one
can distinguish the huts of the
negroes on their slopes. Now I
must ask the reader to use his
imagination to its fullest capacity,
and try to see himself in this harbor in the grey light of early dawn
and watch it become rapidly brighter and then suddenly see the rosy
color of the sunrise tint the tops
of the mountains that rise between
him and the sun, the light gradually
bringing out into vivid relief every
detail of the scene with its gorgeous
dress of tropical foliage, the tall
cocoanut palms telling one that at
last he is in the tropics.

Eventful Geology Trip.

Last Wednesday the class in
Geology I took a most exciting trip.
It will be remembered that the
experiences of the class were
chronicled in Tim NEWS-LETTER
last year when Dr. Swartz, accompanied by a dozen or so of his
hopefuls, boarded a boat at the foot
of Broadway and sailed away to
Hawkins l'oint. The intinerary
this year was nearly the same PS
it was last year. A short stop was
made at the sulphuric acid plant
on Hawkins Point and then the
class followed the shore of the bay
studying the physiographic features
as they went.
The Rock Creek boat does not
return .to Baltimore until late in
the evening so the /class decided to
walk to Curtis Bay and take the
street car from there. The journey
across Hawkins Point was made
at a great speed, the three and
a half miles being covered in
thirty-eight minutes. It was dark
when the tired crowd arrived
at the Baltimore Yacht Club's
grounds on Curtis Bay. But tired
as they were they had to row across
the inlet to Flood's wharf on the
other side. On alighting from one
of the boats a member of the party,
who shall remain nameless, slipped
on the gunwale and went up to
his hip with his right leg in the
water. His spirits were not suppressed however and he joined the
others in singing Hopkins songs
on the back platform of the car on
the homeward trip.
Doctor (to Pat's wife after examining Pat, who has been run
over by an auto)—"Madam I fear
your husband's dead."
Pat (feebly)—"No, I ain't dead
yet."
Pat's Wife—"Hush, Pat, the
gentleman knows better than you."

ANNUAL PRIZES OFFERED
Subjects Announced for Essays to Compete for Hart, Schaffner &
Marx Cash Prizes.

An announcement that will be of
special interest to the students of
economics and political science, but
which also makes a claim upon the
attention of the entire University
is contained in the offer of the
annual Hart, Schaffner and Marx
prizes for the best studies in certain economic fields for the year
1911. The prizes are as follows:
For the two best studies from
Class B, composed of undergradnates in American colleges and universities, a first prize of $300 and
a second prize of $200.
For the two best studies from
Class A, composed of all other persons, a first prize of $1,000 and a
second prize of $500.
The committee which awards the
prizes is composed of Professor J.
Laurence Laughlin, University of
Chicago; Professor J. B. Clark,
Columbia University; Professor
Henry C. Adams, University of
Michigan; Professor Edwin F. Gay,
Harvard University ; Horace White,
Esq., New York City.
The subjects assigned for the
present year are as follows:
1. The History of the Rate of
IMerest in the United States.
2. The Value of Protectionism
to the American Workingman.
3. Economic Reasons for or
Against a Deep Waterway from
the Lakes to the Gulf.
4. German Experience in Taxing the Unearned Increment from
Land.
5. The Valuation of Railways.
6. An Examination of Government Wages Statistics.
7. The Effects of Modern Immigration in the United States.
8. The Value of Organized Speculation.
It is not intended that only subjects in this list shall be used.
Other economic topics may be substituted for these, but only with the
consent of the committee, who
should be consulted before any
other topic is chosen.
The study should be thorough, if
not exhaustive, should be expressed
in good English, and while no limit
is set for its length, should not be
needlessly expanded. The author
is requested to sign an assumed
name to the work and mail it, together with a sealed envelope containing the assumed name and his
real name, to Professor Laughlin,
the chairman of the committee, on
or before June I, 1911.

Prominent University Figures Speak to
Students About College Spirit
and Vigorous Yells are
Rehearsed.

A series of rousing mass-meetings
were held last week to stir up enthusiasm for the St. Johns game.
These were especially important in
enabling the freshmen to rehearse
the yells and songs under the leadership of Harold B. Hering, cheerleader.
Yell practice was omitted at the
mass-meeting held in Hopkins Hall
last Wednesday out of respect to
the memory of the late Dr. Elliott.
This meeting was the most important from
the standpoint of
speeches.
Captain Stollenwerck
was the first speaker. He made an
appeal for more cheering at the
daily football practice at Homewood.
"It puts ginger into us," he said,
"and enables us to play a snapping
game." (Oh, Gingersnaps! Stonie.)
Stollenwerck also tried to break
the overconfident spirit which many
of the students and players had.
Ed Clary made some announcements in regard to the band fund
and parade. Dick McCabe gave a
retrospective account of the previous Hopkins-St. Johns games.
Dr. Magoffin, Johnny Holmes, and
Dick McCabe all said a few words
in regard to celebrating after the
game. Undoubtedly the moral conditions among the student body are
improving, but there is room for
more improvement. Advice coming
from such speakers will be very effective and it produced a wholesome
effect this year. Coach Lynn said
a few words about the team. He
said that Hopkins should not only
heat St. Johns, but that the Soldier
Boys should no,t be allowed to score.
The yell practice at the last
scrimmage on Thursday was rather
poor owing to the inclement
weather. However, it was plainly
shown at all the mass-meetings
that there is not enough college
spirit among the students. At none
of them did the students turn out
as they should have done.

F. Morris Miller, '07, is superintendent of a construction gang,
building the new Philadelphia water
front along .the Schuylkill river.
T. H. Salzer, formerly of the
Class of 1911, is taking a special
course in English at Princeton University.
At the recent inauguration of
President Burton of Smith College, Dr. Florence Rena Sabin of
the Medical School Faculty, received the honorary degree of doctor of science.
G. Ross Veazey, 'io, has been
appointed on a committee at the
University of Maryland, to arrange
for the introduction of the honor
system there.

Arbitration Society's Plans.
The Johns Hopkins Arbitration
Society, which was organized several weeks ago, has decided upon .
two main lines of activity, both of
which are educational in purpose:
First, it proposes to make a collection of books and pamphlets on
subjects relating to peace and arbitration.
hrough the kind permission of Protessor Willoughby
and Dr. Raney, some bboks on the
Hague conferences have been transferred from the political science
library to the new case for reserved
books in the main library. These
books may be taken out over-night
like the other reserved books, and
all students are urged to make use
of them.
Secondly, the Society expects to
have occasional talks by prominent
men on the subject of arbitration.
These talks will be open at first only
to members of the Society, but
public meetings will be held latter.
The following gentlemen have
signified their approval of the
Society by agreeing to act as Honorary Vice-Presidents:
Rev. Oliver Huckel,
Mr. Theodore Marburg,
President Ira Remsen,
Hon. James Brown Scott,
J. II. Van Sickle,
Prof. Westel W. Willoughby.
The Society wishes all the students of the University to realize
that a knowledge of the substantial
progress that is being made toward
world-wide peace is necessary to
a well-rounded education. It invites
all students who are interested in
the subject and who should like to
know more about it to become
members. Application should be
made to the Secretary, Mr.
B.
Price.

T.

Cripples' Column.
The sophomore class sent Pete
Porter, its crack football player,
who was recently operated on for
appendicitis, a handsome Hopkins
pillow as a birthday present last
Thursday. He had recovered sufficiently to sit out in the yard surrounding the Church Home Infirmary; and he is expected back
at the University today.
Everybody was glad to see that
Dick McCabe had improved sufficiently to discard his crutches last
week.
Lynn Meekins, '13, an unfortunate victim of the class rush,
is still obliged to hobble about on
his crutches. Class rushes held at
such a cost are not worth having,
and should be abolished in the
future.
The spectators at the St. Johns
game missed Pieper very much as
linesman.
The way he hopped
along with the pole in the Western
Maryland game was a big attraction. It has been suggested that
Manager 1-Jaynes secure a linesman
with a sprained ankle for the
Carlisle Indian game, as it would
undoubtedly prove a big drawing

card.

Prof. A. MARSHALL ELLIOTT DEAD
Head of Romance Department Succumbs
After Lingering Illness—Was Famous
Scholar and Distinguished Man.

Dr. Aaron Marshall Elliott, the
head of the department of Romance
Languages, died at his home, 1028
North Calvert street, on the morning of Wednesday, November 9,
at 6.15 o'clock, of cancer of the
stomach, after about a year's illness.
All through the fall of 19o9, Dr.
Elliott was able to teach his classes,
although a great sufferer most of
the time. On the first of January,
last, however, his suffering became
so great that he had to give up his
work. From this time to his death
his sufferings were intense, and
although he was taken to Atlantic
City during the summer, the disease progressed so rapidly that.
when he was brought home pn
October 13, his end was daily expected.
Dr. Elliott was one of the most
brilliant men that has ever been
associated with Johns Hopkins, and
k: was through him that the Romance Language department has
acquired its international reputation.
Dr. Elliott was born in Wilmington, N. C., on January 24, 1844.
He took his A. B. at Haverford,
in 1866, and an A. M. degree from
the same college in 1878. He
studied in Europe from 1868 to
1876, at the Universities of France,
Madrid, Munich, and Vienna. On
his return he was appointed associate professor of Romance Languages at Hopkins. In 1877 he
took his Ph.D. degree from Princeton. In 1892 he was advanced to
the rank of professor of Romance
Languages, and has been the head
of the department ever since. He
received a degree of LL. D. from
Wake Forest University in 1891,
and again from Haverford in 1908.
Dr. Elliott was.one of the greatest
modern authorities on • the French
Language, and in 1907 he had the
badge of the Legion of Honor conferred upon him by the French
government, as a recognition of the
work he did in tracing the development of modern French from the
medieval dialect.
On his return from Paris he was
welcomed by Governor Warfield,
Mayor Mahool, President Remsen,
and other notable people.
Mr. George Whitelock, in 1902,
presented the University with a
life-sized painting of Dr. Elliott,
which -at present hangs in McCoy
Hall.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS
INFANT MORTALITY ASSOCIATION
Holds Instructive Meetings in McCoy
Hall with Prominent Speakers and
Interesting Educational Exhibit.

There is now being held in
McCoy Hall an exhibition which
bids fair to become famous in the
crusade for the prevention of infant
mortality. The exhibition is being
held in conjunction with the meeting of the first congress of the
American Association for Study
and Prevention of Infant Mortality.
The meeting of the Association continued through only two days,
Thursday and Friday; but the exhibition will be open until Wednesday, November 16, from io a. in.
to Jo p. m.
The opening session of the Coness was addressed by a number
of prominent men. Among them
were :" Cardinal Gibbons; M. Jusserand, the French ambassador to the
United States; Prof. Irving Fisher,
of Yale; Dr. Abraham Jacobi, of
New York, and Dr. Wm.H. Welch,
of Baltimore. They all spoke on the
subject: "The Duty of a Nation to
Its Potential Citizens." M. Jusserand told of the conditions in France
which are very similar to those in
America, and of the battle which
his nation is carrying on against
death. An association exists in
France which has adopted the
method advocated by the American
organization and met with great
success.
Prof. Irving Fisher, of New
Haven, Conn., where the American
organization was formed less than
a year ago, spoke of the work before the members and the plans
which must be pursued.
Other Hopkins men who addressed the meetings were: Dr. J.
Whitridge Williams, who told what
the obstetrician can do to prevent infant mortality,and Dr.L. F. Barker,
who spoke on the importance of
heredity and environment in the
propagation of kind.
The exhibition is being held
under the direction of the Association but there are exhibitors from
every part of the country. Some of
the exhibitors are:
The Baltimore City- Board of
Health.
The United States Department of
Agriculture.
The California Medical Milk
Commission.
The Chicago Board of Health.
New York City Department of
Health, Division of Hygiene.
Harriet Lane Hospital for Children.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOV. 14, 1910.
Little more than a month remains until the end of the time
allowed by the General Education
Board for raising the $75o,000 required to secure the quarter of a
million offered by that body to the
University. On December 31 the
sum must be actually in hand or
definitely pledged, else the other
amount will not be given. No information is available in the meanwhile bearing upon the success of
the campaign that is in progress
to secure the money, further than
the general, optimistic reports that
have been given out from time to
time. From various sources have
come informal rumors giving assurance that the amount would
surely be secured. The time is
about at hand, however, when
something more than rumor may
be expected. The importance of
the matter to the future of.the University and the profound interest
with which the outcome is being
awaited by Hopkins students cf
the past, the present, and the
future demand that some formal
announcement of the result of the
campaign be forthcoming shortly.
THE NEWS-LETTER hopes that the
news of the completion of the
fund will be made public as soon
as it reasonably can.

THE NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 14, 1910

THE VOYAGE TO JAMAICA
A Member of the Biological
Expedition
Tells of the Trip from Baltimore to Port Antonio.

BY A. R. MIDDLETON,
It has been suggested to me that
an account of some of our experiences on the Hopkins Jamaica
expedition would be acceptable to
T 1E NEWS-LETTER.
On the trip down to Jamaica
several incidents occurred that seem
worthy of mention. It will be remembered by yout readers that
\v hen we sailed from Baltimore,
Halley's Comet was attracting the
attention, of everyone. We on the
ship had an especially fine opportunity of seeing it. Between three
and four o'clock on the morning
of May 13, I got up and went on
deck and I was more than paid
for the effort. • The comet was
east of. the ship, and there were
no objects to obstruct one's view
or dwarf it by comparison. Its
head was close down towards the
eastern horizon, while its tail
stretched as a broad band of light
straight up the sky, finally fading
out at the zenith itself.
The first land we sighted was
San Salvadore, and our captain
very obligingly pointed out to us
the position of the Columbus Monument.
Another interesting sight was our
view of Cuba. We vent quite close
to the eastern end of the island,
SO that every feature of its long
coast line was clearly visible to us.
In profile, near the lighthouse, the
hills show a very remarkable series
of terraces, as evidence of former
Periods of submergence of their
limestone rocks beneath the ocean.
It was surprising to see that there
was apparently no beach, the mountains of the interior ending in foothills and a high and very narrow
coastal plain which presented a low
Cliff to the waters of the Atlantic.
This cliff was perfectly honeycombed with caverns worn in it
by the waves. The vegetation
seemed sparse, the country dry,
almost arid, and 'the greater part
of the long coast presented quite
a forbidding appearance.
We,or rather, our boat, made the
acquaintance of a school of porPoises, which romped along at her
bow for quite a while. One of the
porpoises was, I am sure, given
quite a surprise in the course of his
gambols. He shad gotten off a little
to one side and had lagged behind

his fellows a little, when suddenly
he made a dart to catch up to them
and gave his snout a resounding
thump against the side of the ship.
Then, too, early one morning, we
sighted a large turtlejazily floating along on the surface of the
water. But we were possibly most
interested in the "flying fish," of
which we saw a great many. In
watching them we were reminded of
the discussion as to how they managed to propel themselves through
the air, and we all decided that they
actually fly, i. e., that there is a
vibrating motion of the "wings,"
similar to that of bird wings. We
were led to this conclusion by several reasons: First, there is a
series of ripples produced on the
surface, such as would result from
a succession of blows struck it a
short distance apart; second, we
repeatedly saw the fish change his
direction of flight, sometimes turning almost at right angles to his .
direction on leaving the water;
third, the "flights" were so long
that it seemed to us impossible that
the fish could have gained momentum enough before leaving the
water to enable him to soar so far.
Finally, we reached the conclusion
that we could distinctly see the vibratory motion of the "wings!!
We were unable to study the
plankton forms because the speed
of the ship caused the tow-net to
bound along over the surface of
the waves in long leaps.
One of the most beautiful sights
imaginable was our first view of
Jamaica. Just as the first grey light
of dawn was showing, we were
awakened by the pilot coming
aboard, and soon we were on deck.
At the side of the ship we tould
distinguish the dim outline of the
native dug-out canoe and its three
or four negro paddlers. The canoe
was racing along over the water,
secured to the ship by a tow-line
as she steamed into the harbor of
Port Antonio.
To the east, Folly Point juts far
out into the water, and at its extreme end is the Folly Point Light.
On the west, the harbor is protected
by a large island, and a series of
reefs between it and the "mainland," so that the harbor is only
open towards the north. There is
a very narrow but comfortable
channel for the steamships,of which
there are an abundance. It is said
that Port Antonio clears more ships
Eor American ports than any other
city in the world. The town is
built on a narrow coastal plain; the

FOOT BALL
U. S. NAVAL ACADEMY

mountains are so close that from
the deck of a ship in the port one
can distinguish the huts of the
negroes on their slopes. Now I
must ask the reader to use his
imagination to its fullest capacity,
and try to see himself in this harbor in the grey light of early dawn
and watch it become rapidly brighter and then suddenly see the rosy
color of the sunrise tint the tops
of the mountains that rise between
him and the sun, the light gradually
bringing out into vivid relief every
detail of the scene with its gorgeous
dress of tropical foliage, the tall
cocoanut palms telling one that at
last he is in the tropics.
(To be Continued)
Eventful Geology Trip.

Last Wednesday the class in
Geology I took a most exciting trip.
It will be remembered that the
experiences of the class were
chronicled in Tim NEWS-LETTER
last year when Dr. Swartz, accompanied by a dozen or so of his
hopefuls, boarded a boat at the foot
of Broadway and sailed away to
Hawkins l'oint. The intinerary
this year was nearly the same PS
it was last year. A short stop was
made at the sulphuric acid plant
on Hawkins Point and then the
class followed the shore of the bay
studying the physiographic features
as they went.
The Rock Creek boat does not
return .to Baltimore until late in
the evening so the /class decided to
walk to Curtis Bay and take the
street car from there. The journey
across Hawkins Point was made
at a great speed, the three and
a half miles being covered in
thirty-eight minutes. It was dark
when the tired crowd arrived
at the Baltimore Yacht Club's
grounds on Curtis Bay. But tired
as they were they had to row across
the inlet to Flood's wharf on the
other side. On alighting from one
of the boats a member of the party,
who shall remain nameless, slipped
on the gunwale and went up to
his hip with his right leg in the
water. His spirits were not suppressed however and he joined the
others in singing Hopkins songs
on the back platform of the car on
the homeward trip.
Doctor (to Pat's wife after examining Pat, who has been run
over by an auto)—"Madam I fear
your husband's dead."
Pat (feebly)—"No, I ain't dead
yet."
Pat's Wife—"Hush, Pat, the
gentleman knows better than you."

ANNUAL PRIZES OFFERED
Subjects Announced for Essays to Compete for Hart, Schaffner &
Marx Cash Prizes.

An announcement that will be of
special interest to the students of
economics and political science, but
which also makes a claim upon the
attention of the entire University
is contained in the offer of the
annual Hart, Schaffner and Marx
prizes for the best studies in certain economic fields for the year
1911. The prizes are as follows:
For the two best studies from
Class B, composed of undergradnates in American colleges and universities, a first prize of $300 and
a second prize of $200.
For the two best studies from
Class A, composed of all other persons, a first prize of $1,000 and a
second prize of $500.
The committee which awards the
prizes is composed of Professor J.
Laurence Laughlin, University of
Chicago; Professor J. B. Clark,
Columbia University; Professor
Henry C. Adams, University of
Michigan; Professor Edwin F. Gay,
Harvard University ; Horace White,
Esq., New York City.
The subjects assigned for the
present year are as follows:
1. The History of the Rate of
IMerest in the United States.
2. The Value of Protectionism
to the American Workingman.
3. Economic Reasons for or
Against a Deep Waterway from
the Lakes to the Gulf.
4. German Experience in Taxing the Unearned Increment from
Land.
5. The Valuation of Railways.
6. An Examination of Government Wages Statistics.
7. The Effects of Modern Immigration in the United States.
8. The Value of Organized Speculation.
It is not intended that only subjects in this list shall be used.
Other economic topics may be substituted for these, but only with the
consent of the committee, who
should be consulted before any
other topic is chosen.
The study should be thorough, if
not exhaustive, should be expressed
in good English, and while no limit
is set for its length, should not be
needlessly expanded. The author
is requested to sign an assumed
name to the work and mail it, together with a sealed envelope containing the assumed name and his
real name, to Professor Laughlin,
the chairman of the committee, on
or before June I, 1911.

Prominent University Figures Speak to
Students About College Spirit
and Vigorous Yells are
Rehearsed.

A series of rousing mass-meetings
were held last week to stir up enthusiasm for the St. Johns game.
These were especially important in
enabling the freshmen to rehearse
the yells and songs under the leadership of Harold B. Hering, cheerleader.
Yell practice was omitted at the
mass-meeting held in Hopkins Hall
last Wednesday out of respect to
the memory of the late Dr. Elliott.
This meeting was the most important from
the standpoint of
speeches.
Captain Stollenwerck
was the first speaker. He made an
appeal for more cheering at the
daily football practice at Homewood.
"It puts ginger into us," he said,
"and enables us to play a snapping
game." (Oh, Gingersnaps! Stonie.)
Stollenwerck also tried to break
the overconfident spirit which many
of the students and players had.
Ed Clary made some announcements in regard to the band fund
and parade. Dick McCabe gave a
retrospective account of the previous Hopkins-St. Johns games.
Dr. Magoffin, Johnny Holmes, and
Dick McCabe all said a few words
in regard to celebrating after the
game. Undoubtedly the moral conditions among the student body are
improving, but there is room for
more improvement. Advice coming
from such speakers will be very effective and it produced a wholesome
effect this year. Coach Lynn said
a few words about the team. He
said that Hopkins should not only
heat St. Johns, but that the Soldier
Boys should no,t be allowed to score.
The yell practice at the last
scrimmage on Thursday was rather
poor owing to the inclement
weather. However, it was plainly
shown at all the mass-meetings
that there is not enough college
spirit among the students. At none
of them did the students turn out
as they should have done.

Arbitration Society's Plans.
The Johns Hopkins Arbitration
Society, which was organized several weeks ago, has decided upon .
two main lines of activity, both of
which are educational in purpose:
First, it proposes to make a collection of books and pamphlets on
subjects relating to peace and arbitration.
hrough the kind permission of Protessor Willoughby
and Dr. Raney, some bboks on the
Hague conferences have been transferred from the political science
library to the new case for reserved
books in the main library. These
books may be taken out over-night
like the other reserved books, and
all students are urged to make use
of them.
Secondly, the Society expects to
have occasional talks by prominent
men on the subject of arbitration.
These talks will be open at first only
to members of the Society, but
public meetings will be held latter.
The following gentlemen have
signified their approval of the
Society by agreeing to act as Honorary Vice-Presidents:
Rev. Oliver Huckel,
Mr. Theodore Marburg,
President Ira Remsen,
Hon. James Brown Scott,
J. II. Van Sickle,
Prof. Westel W. Willoughby.
The Society wishes all the students of the University to realize
that a knowledge of the substantial
progress that is being made toward
world-wide peace is necessary to
a well-rounded education. It invites
all students who are interested in
the subject and who should like to
know more about it to become
members. Application should be
made to the Secretary, Mr.
B.
Price.

Cripples' Column.
The sophomore class sent Pete
Porter, its crack football player,
who was recently operated on for
appendicitis, a handsome Hopkins
pillow as a birthday present last
Thursday. He had recovered sufficiently to sit out in the yard surrounding the Church Home Infirmary; and he is expected back
at the University today.
Everybody was glad to see that
Dick McCabe had improved sufficiently to discard his crutches last
week.
Lynn Meekins, '13, an unfortunate victim of the class rush,
is still obliged to hobble about on
his crutches. Class rushes held at
such a cost are not worth having,
and should be abolished in the
future.

game missed Pieper very much as
linesman.
The way he hopped
along with the pole in the Western
Maryland game was a big attraction. It has been suggested that
Manager 1-Jaynes secure a linesman
with a sprained ankle for the
Carlisle Indian game, as it would
undoubtedly prove a big drawing

card.
